The **2018 UEFA Champions League Final** was the final match of the [2017–18
UEFA Champions League](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League "2017–18
UEFA Champions League"), the 63rd season of Europe's premier club football
tournament organised by [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA"), and the 26th season since
it was renamed from the European Cup to the [UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League"). It was played at
the [NSC Olimpiyskiy Stadium](/wiki/Olimpiyskiy_National_Sports_Complex
"Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex") in [Kiev](/wiki/Kiev "Kiev"), Ukraine
on 26 May 2018,[5] between [Spanish](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Football_Federation
"Royal Spanish Football Federation") side and defending champions [Real
Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid C.F."), who had won the
competition in each of the last two seasons, and
[English](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football Association") side
[Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C.").[6][7]

Real Madrid won the final 3–1 for their third consecutive and 13th overall
Champions League title, becoming the first team to achieve three back-to-back
titles since [Bayern Munich](/wiki/1975%E2%80%9376_FC_Bayern_Munich_season
"1975–76 FC Bayern Munich season") defeated [Saint-
Étienne](/wiki/AS_Saint-%C3%89tienne "AS Saint-Étienne") in the [1976 European
Cup Final](/wiki/1976_European_Cup_Final "1976 European Cup Final"); it was
additionally their fourth title in five seasons. They also earned the right to
play the winners of the [2017–18 UEFA Europa
League](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Europa_League "2017–18 UEFA Europa
League"), [Atlético Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid"), in
the [2018 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2018_UEFA_Super_Cup "2018 UEFA Super Cup") and
to enter the semi-finals of the [2018 FIFA Club World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2018 FIFA Club World Cup"). They also
qualified to enter the group stage of the [2018–19 UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Champions_League "2018–19 UEFA Champions
League"),[8] but since they already qualified through their league
performance, the berth reserved was given to the champions of the [2017–18
Czech First League](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Czech_First_League "2017–18 Czech
First League"), the 11th-ranked association according to next season's access
list.[9]

##
Venue[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Venue")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kyiv_NSC_Olimpiyskyi_6.jpg/220px-
Kyiv_NSC_Olimpiyskyi_6.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kyiv_NSC_Olimpiyskyi_6.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kyiv_NSC_Olimpiyskyi_6.jpg "Enlarge")

The [NSC Olimpiyskiy Stadium](/wiki/Olimpiyskiy_National_Sports_Complex
"Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex") in [Kiev](/wiki/Kiev "Kiev") hosted the
final

The [NSC Olimpiyskiy Stadium](/wiki/Olimpiyskiy_National_Sports_Complex
"Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex") was announced as the final venue on 15
September 2016, following the decision of the UEFA Executive Committee meeting
in [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), Greece.[5] This was the sixth European
Cup/Champions League final hosted at an [Eastern
European](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe") venue following those in
[1973](/wiki/1973_European_Cup_Final "1973 European Cup Final") in
[Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade"),[10] [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia
"Yugoslavia"), the [1983](/wiki/1983_European_Cup_Final "1983 European Cup
Final"), [1994](/wiki/1994_European_Cup_Final "1994 European Cup Final") and
[2007](/wiki/2007_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2007 UEFA Champions League
Final") finals hosted by [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"),[11][12][13]
[Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece") as well as the [2008
final](/wiki/2008_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2008 UEFA Champions League
Final") in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow"), [Russia](/wiki/Russia
"Russia").[14]

The Olimpiyskiy Stadium was built in 1923 and it has been renovated three
times, most recently in 2011 in preparation for the [UEFA Euro
2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012") tournament.[15] The stadium was
used as a venue in the [1980 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980
Summer Olympics") for its
[football](/wiki/Football_at_the_1980_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1980
Summer Olympics") event and the aforementioned European Championship,[16]
including the [final match](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012_Final "UEFA Euro 2012
Final"), which saw [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team") beat [Italy](/wiki/Italian_national_football_team "Italian
national football team") by the record-breaking score of 4–0 on the way to
their third title.[17] Its current capacity is 70,050 and it is used by the
[Ukraine national football team](/wiki/Ukraine_national_football_team "Ukraine
national football team"), [Dynamo Kyiv](/wiki/FC_Dynamo_Kyiv "FC Dynamo
Kyiv"), and major domestic matches like the [Ukrainian
Cup](/wiki/Ukrainian_Cup "Ukrainian Cup").[18][19]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Background")]

Defending champions [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid C.F.")
reached a record 16th final after a 4–3 aggregate win against
[German](/wiki/Bundesliga "Bundesliga") side [Bayern
Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich"), knocking them out of the
competition for the second consecutive season. This was Real Madrid's third
consecutive final, and fourth final in five tournaments with an opportunity to
win a [record 13th
title](/wiki/European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_records_and_statistics
"European Cup and UEFA Champions League records and statistics"). Previously
they won finals in [1956](/wiki/1956_European_Cup_Final "1956 European Cup
Final"), [1957](/wiki/1957_European_Cup_Final "1957 European Cup Final"),
[1958](/wiki/1958_European_Cup_Final "1958 European Cup Final"),
[1959](/wiki/1959_European_Cup_Final "1959 European Cup Final"),
[1960](/wiki/1960_European_Cup_Final "1960 European Cup Final"),
[1966](/wiki/1966_European_Cup_Final "1966 European Cup Final"),
[1998](/wiki/1998_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1998 UEFA Champions League
Final"), [2000](/wiki/2000_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2000 UEFA Champions
League Final"), [2002](/wiki/2002_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2002 UEFA
Champions League Final"), [2014](/wiki/2014_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2014
UEFA Champions League Final"), [2016](/wiki/2016_UEFA_Champions_League_Final
"2016 UEFA Champions League Final") and
[2017](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2017 UEFA Champions League
Final"); and lost in [1962](/wiki/1962_European_Cup_Final "1962 European Cup
Final"), [1964](/wiki/1964_European_Cup_Final "1964 European Cup Final") and
[1981](/wiki/1981_European_Cup_Final "1981 European Cup Final"). This was also
their 20th final in all seasonal UEFA competitions, having also played in two
[Cup Winners' Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup")
finals (losing in [1971](/wiki/1971_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_Final "1971
European Cup Winners' Cup Final") and
[1983](/wiki/1983_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_Final "1983 European Cup
Winners' Cup Final")) and two [UEFA Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa
League") finals (winning in [1985](/wiki/1985_UEFA_Cup_Final "1985 UEFA Cup
Final") and [1986](/wiki/1986_UEFA_Cup_Final "1986 UEFA Cup Final")). Real
Madrid are only the third team since the competition's rebranding as the
Champions League to reach three consecutive finals after
[Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C. Milan") in
[1995](/wiki/1995_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1995 UEFA Champions League
Final") and [Juventus](/wiki/Juventus_F.C. "Juventus F.C.") in
[1998](/wiki/1998_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1998 UEFA Champions League
Final"). They are the first team in the Champions League era, and the fourth
overall, to win three straight finals, a feat only achieved by the Real Madrid
side of the 1950s, as they went on to win a record five successive finals, as
well as the [Ajax](/wiki/AFC_Ajax "AFC Ajax") and [Bayern
Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich") squads of the 1970s in
[1973](/wiki/1973_European_Cup_Final "1973 European Cup Final") and
[1976](/wiki/1976_European_Cup_Final "1976 European Cup Final"),
respectively.[20]

[Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C.") reached their eighth final,
their first since [2007](/wiki/2007_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2007 UEFA
Champions League Final"), after a 7–6 aggregate win against
[Italian](/wiki/Serie_A "Serie A") side [Roma](/wiki/A.S._Roma "A.S.
Roma").[21] They have won the final on five occasions
([1977](/wiki/1977_European_Cup_Final "1977 European Cup Final"),
[1978](/wiki/1978_European_Cup_Final "1978 European Cup Final"),
[1981](/wiki/1981_European_Cup_Final "1981 European Cup Final"),
[1984](/wiki/1984_European_Cup_Final "1984 European Cup Final") and
[2005](/wiki/2005_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2005 UEFA Champions League
Final")), and have lost twice ([1985](/wiki/1985_European_Cup_Final "1985
European Cup Final") and [2007](/wiki/2007_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2007
UEFA Champions League Final")). This was also their 13th final in UEFA
seasonal competitions, having played in one [Cup Winners'
Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup") final (losing in
[1966](/wiki/1966_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_Final "1966 European Cup
Winners' Cup Final")) and four [UEFA Cup/Europa
League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League") finals (winning in
[1973](/wiki/1973_UEFA_Cup_Final "1973 UEFA Cup Final"),
[1976](/wiki/1976_UEFA_Cup_Final "1976 UEFA Cup Final") and
[2001](/wiki/2001_UEFA_Cup_Final "2001 UEFA Cup Final"); and losing in
[2016](/wiki/2016_UEFA_Europa_League_Final "2016 UEFA Europa League
Final")).[22] Liverpool were the first team since [Bayern
Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich") in
[2011–12](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_UEFA_Champions_League "2011–12 UEFA Champions
League") to reach the final having qualified for the competition through the
[play-off
round](/wiki/2017-18_UEFA_Champions_League_qualifying_phase_and_play-off_round
"2017-18 UEFA Champions League qualifying phase and play-off round"). This was
also the most recent occasion the final featured an English team
([Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.")).[23] Liverpool were the most
recent team to defeat Real Madrid in a European Cup Final, winning 1–0 in
Paris in [1981](/wiki/1981_European_Cup_Final "1981 European Cup Final").[24]

Besides the 1981 final, the two teams have played each other four times in the
Champions League era. Liverpool won both matches in the [2008–09 UEFA
Champions League](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_UEFA_Champions_League "2008–09 UEFA
Champions League") round of 16, while Real Madrid won both matches in the
[2014–15 UEFA Champions League](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_UEFA_Champions_League
"2014–15 UEFA Champions League") group stage.[25]

## Pre-
match[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Pre-match")]

###
Ambassador[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Ambassador")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Andriy_Shevchenko_2015.jpg/170px-
Andriy_Shevchenko_2015.jpg)](/wiki/File:Andriy_Shevchenko_2015.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Andriy_Shevchenko_2015.jpg "Enlarge")

[Andriy Shevchenko](/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko "Andriy Shevchenko") was named as
the ambassador for the final.

The ambassador for the final was former Ukrainian international [Andriy
Shevchenko](/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko "Andriy Shevchenko"), who won the UEFA
Champions League with [Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C. Milan") in
[2003](/wiki/2003_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2003 UEFA Champions League
Final").[26]

###
Ticketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Ticketing")]

With a stadium capacity of 63,000 for the final, a total of 40,700 tickets are
available to fans and the general public, with the two finalist teams
receiving 17,000 tickets each and with 6,700 tickets being available for sale
to fans worldwide via UEFA.com from 15 to 22 March 2018 in four price
categories: €450, €320, €160, and €70. The remaining tickets are allocated to
the local organising committee, UEFA and national associations, commercial
partners and broadcasters, and to serve the corporate hospitality
programme.[27][28]

### Opening
ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Opening ceremony")]

English singer [Dua Lipa](/wiki/Dua_Lipa "Dua Lipa") performed at the opening
ceremony preceding the final.[29] Jamaican rapper [Sean Paul](/wiki/Sean_Paul
"Sean Paul") joined her as a special guest to perform their collaborative
song, "[No Lie](/wiki/No_Lie_\(Sean_Paul_song\) "No Lie \(Sean Paul
song\)")".[30]

show

  3. "[Be the One](/wiki/Be_the_One_\(Dua_Lipa_song\) "Be the One \(Dua Lipa song\)")"

  5. "[New Rules](/wiki/New_Rules_\(song\) "New Rules \(song\)")"

### Related
events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Related events")]

The [2018 UEFA Women's Champions League
Final](/wiki/2018_UEFA_Women%27s_Champions_League_Final "2018 UEFA Women's
Champions League Final") was held two days earlier, on 24 May 2018, at the
[Valeriy Lobanovskyi Dynamo Stadium](/wiki/Valeriy_Lobanovskyi_Dynamo_Stadium
"Valeriy Lobanovskyi Dynamo Stadium") between
[Wolfsburg](/wiki/VfL_Wolfsburg_\(women\) "VfL Wolfsburg \(women\)") and
[Lyon](/wiki/Olympique_Lyonnais_F%C3%A9minin "Olympique Lyonnais Féminin"),
Lyon emerging victorious 4–1.[31] This was also the last time that the host
city for the men's Champions League final was also automatically assigned the
Women's Champions League final.[32]

The annual UEFA Champions Festival was held between 24–27 May 2018 at the Kiev
city centre.[33]

###
Incidents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Incidents")]

In late May, _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_ reported that some fans with allocated tickets had returned them
after having trouble finding flights to and accommodation in Kiev. Locals in
Kiev began offering free accommodation for fans affected by cancelled hotel
and apartment arrangements.[34] Several [charter
flights](/wiki/Charter_flights "Charter flights") arranged for Liverpool fans
were cancelled, leaving fans with tickets stranded and leading to an
unsuccessful search for alternative solutions by the club and city
government.[35][36] Other airlines offered flights to Kiev from airports in
Liverpool and Manchester, using assigned slots at Kiev's airports.[37]

On 24 May, a group of Liverpool fans were attacked in a restaurant by 20
masked hooligans.[38]

##
Match[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Match")]

###
Officials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Officials")]

On 7 May 2018, UEFA announced that Serbian [Milorad
Mažić](/wiki/Milorad_Ma%C5%BEi%C4%87 "Milorad Mažić") would officiate the
final. Mažić has been a [FIFA referee](/wiki/FIFA_International_Referees_List
"FIFA International Referees List") since 2009, and gained UEFA's elite
referee status in 2013. He was joined by his fellow countrymen, with Milovan
Ristić and Dalibor Đurdević as assistant referees, Nenad Đokić and Danilo
Grujić as additional assistant referees, and Nemanja Petrović as reserve
assistant referee. The fourth official for the final was Frenchman [Clément
Turpin](/wiki/Cl%C3%A9ment_Turpin "Clément Turpin").[2]

###
Summary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Summary")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Gareth_Bale_2015_%289%29.jpg/170px-
Gareth_Bale_2015_%289%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gareth_Bale_2015_\(9\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gareth_Bale_2015_\(9\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Gareth Bale](/wiki/Gareth_Bale "Gareth Bale") entered the match as a
substitute in the 61st minute and scored two goals for Madrid

The match began with Liverpool's kickoff and the team's successive attacks to
counter Madrid's slower, possession-based buildup. In the 23rd minute, a low
shot by [Trent Alexander-Arnold](/wiki/Trent_Alexander-Arnold "Trent
Alexander-Arnold") went through a defender's legs and forced a late save by
[Keylor Navas](/wiki/Keylor_Navas "Keylor Navas"). Two minutes later,
Liverpool forward [Mohamed Salah](/wiki/Mohamed_Salah "Mohamed Salah") was
injured competing for the ball with [Sergio Ramos](/wiki/Sergio_Ramos "Sergio
Ramos"), who had locked Salah's arm resulting in a fall.[39][40] Due to a
[dislocated shoulder](/wiki/Dislocated_shoulder "Dislocated shoulder"), Salah
was substituted four minutes later for [Adam Lallana](/wiki/Adam_Lallana "Adam
Lallana").[41] Madrid's [Dani Carvajal](/wiki/Dani_Carvajal "Dani Carvajal")
was substituted in the 37th minute with a [hamstring](/wiki/Hamstring
"Hamstring") injury after an unsuccessful [backheel](/wiki/Backheel
"Backheel").[42] Minutes later, [Karim Benzema](/wiki/Karim_Benzema "Karim
Benzema")'s goal was disallowed after he was determined to be offside while
finishing a shot started by [Cristiano Ronaldo](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo
"Cristiano Ronaldo")'s header. The first half ended scoreless, with Madrid
dominating possession but Liverpool having more chances to score.[39][41]

The second half began with a shot by [Isco](/wiki/Isco "Isco"), who hit the
crossbar. In the 51st minute, Benzema scored the match's first goal by
deflecting a throw by Liverpool goalkeeper [Loris Karius](/wiki/Loris_Karius
"Loris Karius") back into the net. Liverpool equalised four minutes later with
a tap-in by [Sadio Mané](/wiki/Sadio_Man%C3%A9 "Sadio Mané"), who finished a
header by [Dejan Lovren](/wiki/Dejan_Lovren "Dejan Lovren") after a corner
kick by [James Milner](/wiki/James_Milner "James Milner") from the right.[43]
[Gareth Bale](/wiki/Gareth_Bale "Gareth Bale") was substituted in for Isco in
the 61st minute and scored Madrid's second goal two minutes later, using an
acrobatic [bicycle kick](/wiki/Bicycle_kick "Bicycle kick") to finish a cross
by [Marcelo](/wiki/Marcelo_\(footballer,_born_1988\) "Marcelo \(footballer,
born 1988\)") from the left.[44] Liverpool pressed for a second equalising
goal, with a shot by Mané that hit the goal post and calls for a
[penalty](/wiki/Penalty_kick_\(association_football\) "Penalty kick
\(association football\)") for an alleged [handball](/wiki/Handball
"Handball"), but were also losing possession to Madrid. Ronaldo had a chance
to score his first goal of the match during a counterattack in the 73rd
minute, but was tackled by Liverpool defender [Andrew
Robertson](/wiki/Andrew_Robertson_\(footballer\) "Andrew Robertson
\(footballer\)") in the penalty box. Bale scored his second goal of the match
in the 83rd minute on a 40-yard (37 m) shot that swerved in front of Karius
and went through his hands and into the net. A second chance on goal for
Ronaldo in the 93rd minute of play was interrupted by a [pitch
invader](/wiki/Pitch_invasion "Pitch invasion"), who was captured by stadium
stewards.[39][41]

## Post-
match[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Post-match")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/2018_Ukraine_Stamp_08.jpg/170px-2018_Ukraine_Stamp_08.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018_Ukraine_Stamp_08.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2018_Ukraine_Stamp_08.jpg "Enlarge")

[Postage stamp](/wiki/Postage_stamp "Postage stamp") of
[Ukraine](/wiki/Ukrposhta "Ukrposhta"), 2018

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Real_Madrid_C.F._the_Winner_Of_The_Champions_League_in_2018_%281%29.jpg/220px-
Real_Madrid_C.F._the_Winner_Of_The_Champions_League_in_2018_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Real_Madrid_C.F._the_Winner_Of_The_Champions_League_in_2018_\(1\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Real_Madrid_C.F._the_Winner_Of_The_Champions_League_in_2018_\(1\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Captain [Sergio Ramos](/wiki/Sergio_Ramos "Sergio Ramos") hoisting the
[European Champion Clubs' Cup](/wiki/European_Champion_Clubs%27_Cup "European
Champion Clubs' Cup") as Real Madrid celebrate winning the final

Real Madrid became the first team since [Bayern Munich](/wiki/Bayern_Munich
"Bayern Munich") in 1974–76 to win three consecutive UEFA Champions Leagues or
European Cups.[44] The title was Madrid's 13th, another Champions League
record, and their fourth in five years.[44] Real Madrid's victory was the
fifth consecutive title for a Spanish side in the Champions League, becoming
the longest run for the trophy to be held by teams from the same country since
English sides won six consecutive titles between 1977 and 1982.[48]

Manager [Zinedine Zidane](/wiki/Zinedine_Zidane "Zinedine Zidane") became the
first to win three consecutive Champions League titles and matched [Carlo
Ancelotti](/wiki/Carlo_Ancelotti "Carlo Ancelotti")'s record of Champions
League era wins.[49] Five days after the final, Zidane announced that he would
step down as manager in favour of a "different voice".[50] [Cristiano
Ronaldo](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo "Cristiano Ronaldo") became the first player
to win the Champions League five times, surpassing the record set by [Clarence
Seedorf](/wiki/Clarence_Seedorf "Clarence Seedorf") in 2007 and by [Andrés
Iniesta](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Iniesta "Andrés Iniesta") in 2015.[51]

[Gareth Bale](/wiki/Gareth_Bale "Gareth Bale") became the first substitute to
score two goals in a Champions League final and was named [man of the
match](/wiki/Man_of_the_match "Man of the match").[52][53] His first goal
received acclaim as one of the best in Champions League history and was
compared to Ronaldo's bicycle kick goal against Juventus in the quarter-final
and manager [Zinedine Zidane](/wiki/Zinedine_Zidane "Zinedine Zidane")'s goal
in the [2002 final](/wiki/2002_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2002 UEFA
Champions League Final").[39][54]

[Sergio Ramos](/wiki/Sergio_Ramos "Sergio Ramos")'s tackle on [Mohamed
Salah](/wiki/Mohamed_Salah "Mohamed Salah") received mixed reactions from the
press and fans on whether the injury was the result of a deliberate blow or an
accident.[55] Egyptian fans responded with anger on social media, including
insults that became trending topics on [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter").[56]
A [Change.org](/wiki/Change.org "Change.org") petition calling on
[UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") and [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA") to punish Ramos for
the challenge received 400,000 signatures within two days.[57] A separate
incident involving Ramos and Liverpool goalkeeper [Loris
Karius](/wiki/Loris_Karius "Loris Karius") raised questions after a video
showed him allegedly elbowing Karius in the face prior to his first
goalkeeping error.[58][59] UEFA declined to take action against Ramos for the
incident with Karius.[60] After an examination, on 4 June 2018, physiatrist
[Ross Zafonte](/wiki/Ross_Zafonte "Ross Zafonte") at the [Massachusetts
General Hospital](/wiki/Massachusetts_General_Hospital "Massachusetts General
Hospital") said in a statement that Karius suffered a
[concussion](/wiki/Concussion "Concussion") during the match and that,
according to him, it was possible the concussion would affect the player's
performance.[61]

Liverpool manager [Jürgen Klopp](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Klopp "Jürgen Klopp") lost
his sixth of seven major finals, including Champions League and league
cups.[43] After the match, Loris Karius tearfully apologised to Liverpool
supporters who remained in the stands and stated that his mistakes "lost the
team the final".[62] After the match, Karius received online [death
threats](/wiki/Death_threats "Death threats") and hate messages directed at
him and his family.[63]
